title: 113_s1659
content: The Act may be cited as the "Protecting Our Students and Taxpayers Act of 2013" or "POST Act of 2013". It includes the 85/15 rule. The Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to include a new requirement for proprietary institutions of higher education to derive at least 15 percent of their revenues from specific sources to qualify under the Act. The Higher Education Act of 1965 now mandates that proprietary institutions must generate 15 percent of their revenues from non-Federal funds to meet the Act's requirements. Federal funds refer to financial assistance provided by the government through various means, excluding housing stipends from the Post-9/11 Veterans Educational Assistance Program. The Higher Education Act of 1965 requires proprietary institutions to generate 15% of their revenue from non-Federal sources. Institutions must use cash basis accounting and only consider revenue from tuition, fees, and activities necessary for education and training. The Higher Education Act of 1965 mandates that proprietary institutions must generate 15% of their revenue from non-Federal sources. This requirement applies to activities related to education and training conducted on campus under faculty supervision and required for all students in a specific program. The Higher Education Act of 1965 requires proprietary institutions to generate 15% of revenue from non-Federal sources. This includes job training for low-income individuals and the use of Federal funds for student tuition and fees. The Higher Education Act of 1965 mandates that proprietary institutions must obtain 15% of revenue from non-Federal sources, which includes grants from external sources and institutional scholarships. Loans from the institution cannot be counted as revenue, except for student loan payments. The Higher Education Act of 1965 requires proprietary institutions to receive 15% of revenue from non-Federal sources, including external grants and institutional scholarships based on academic achievements or financial need. These scholarships must be disbursed to qualified students from a restricted account funded by designated funds or income from an outside source with no affiliation. The Higher Education Act of 1965 mandates that proprietary institutions must receive 15% of revenue from non-Federal sources, including external grants and institutional scholarships. These scholarships must be disbursed to qualified students from a restricted account funded by designated funds or income from an outside source with no affiliation or shared employees with the institution. Excluded from revenues are funds received under specific titles and matching funds provided by the institution. The Secretary must report to Congress annually by July 1 on the amount of Federal funds provided to institutions for student charges, including refunds, and the amount charged for books, supplies, and equipment. The Secretary must report to Congress annually on the amount of Federal funds received by proprietary institutions of higher education, as well as the percentage of revenues from Federal funds and other sources. Section 487 of the Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to repeal certain requirements. The Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended by striking and redesignating paragraphs, subsections, and inserting new subsections. Subsection (d) is removed and subsections (e) through (j) are redesignated. Changes are made to subsections (f)(1) and (g)(1). In subsection (g)(1), the text is amended by replacing "subsection (a)(27)" with "subsection (a)(26)". Conforming amendments are made to various sections of the Higher Education Act of 1965. In section 496(c)(3)(A) and section 498(k)(1), "section 487(f)" is replaced with "section 487(e)".
